context: The French acquired a copy of the <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>British<a0_1/> war plans<a0_3/><a0_2/>, including the activities of <a0_0><a0_4><b4_0><b5_0>Shirley and Johnson<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_4/>.<a0_0/> Shirley's <a1_0><b6_0>efforts to fortify Oswego were bogged down in <a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4>logistical<a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_1/> difficulties<b6_0/><a1_2/>, exacerbated by Shirley's inexperience<a1_0/> in managing large expeditions. In conjunction, Shirley was made aware that the French were massing for an attack on Fort Oswego in his absence when he <a2_0>planned to attack <a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><b7_0>Fort Niagara<b7_0/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. As a response, Shirley left <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b8_0>garrisons<b8_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> at Oswego, Fort Bull, and Fort Williams (the latter two located on the Oneida Carry between the Mohawk River and Wood Creek at present-day Rome, New York). Supplies for use in the projected attack on Niagara were cached at Fort Bull.
